(4) API ≠ API Description



What are API Description Formats Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(5) Consuming based on Shared Understanding



What are API Description Formats Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(6) Are Descriptions Documentation?

  • Yes, but…
  • APIs should be described in a standardized way
  • APIs are intended for consumption by machines
  • Machine-readable documentation is called description
    • Or: Human-readable description is called documentation
  • APIs should always publish descriptions


What are API Description Formats Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(7) To Each Their Own

  • API space evolution → Description language co-evolution
  • Today's APIs often use HTTP and a resource-based approach
    • Competing languages for this space were RAML and Blueprint
  • Other approaches are supported by other description languages
    • GraphQL for Query-based APIs
    • AsyncAPI for Event-based APIs
    • gRPC for programming distributed systems


Why OpenAPI is Popular

Outline (Why OpenAPI is Popular)

  1. What are API Description Formats [4]
  2. Why OpenAPI is Popular [5]
  3. OpenAPI as a Machine-Readable Format [5]
  4. OpenAPI Superstructure: Resources, Interactions, and Representations [6]
Why OpenAPI is Popular Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(9) REST Rules

  • External APIs have gravitated towards HTTP/REST
    • Simple and intuitive API style and tech stack
    • Good fit for client-initiated synchronous interactions
  • Internal APIs have a bit more diversity
    • OpenAPI for request-based services
    • GraphQL for flexible front-ends
    • AsyncAPI for event-driven services
    • gRPC for remote procedure calls
  • OpenAPI has the largest combined market in the API space


Why OpenAPI is Popular Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(10) Plenty of API Lifecycle Tooling

  • Design tools to help create and discuss APIs
  • Validation tools to make sure APIs adhere to guidelines
  • Mocking tools to generate APIs from descriptions
  • Testing tools to validate implementations against descriptions
  • Fuzzing tools to test APIs for robustness
  • Documentation tools to create API documentation
  • Code generation tools for client and server sides


Why OpenAPI is Popular Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(11) OpenAPI Tooling



Why OpenAPI is Popular Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(12) API Landscape



Why OpenAPI is Popular Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(13) The Open API Lingua Franca

  • OpenAPI benefits from the network effect
  • Technologists can easily talk about designs
  • Organisations have a way to describe their building blocks
  • Teams can communicate in a more scalable way
  • Communications are possible across all these areas


OpenAPI as a Machine-Readable Format

OpenAPI as a Machine-Readable Format Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(15) OpenAPI is Structured Data

  • APIs described by OpenAPI are described in a structured way
  • Resources [OpenAPI Resources: URIs (1)], operations [OpenAPI Operations: HTTP (1)], and representations [OpenAPI Representations: JSON (1)] are core concepts
  • OpenAPI uses a structured way to describe these concepts


OpenAPI as a Machine-Readable Format Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(16) OpenAPI Object Structure



OpenAPI as a Machine-Readable Format Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(17) Minimal OpenAPI in JSON 

{ "openapi": "3.1.0",
  "info": {
    "title": "Greeting API",
    "version": "1.0.0",
    "description": "A simple API to return a greeting message."
  },
  "paths": {
    "/greet": {
      "get": {
        "summary": "Returns a greeting message",
        "responses": {
          "200": {
          "description": "A successful response",
          "content": {
            "application/json": {
              "schema": {
                "type": "object",
                "properties": {
                  "message": {
                    "type": "string",
                    "examples":
                      ["Hello, world!"] }}}}}}}}}}}
  • greet.json


OpenAPI as a Machine-Readable Format Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(18) Minimal OpenAPI in YAML 

openapi: 3.1.0
info:
  title: Greeting API
  version: 1.0.0
  description: A simple API to return a greeting message.

paths:
  /greet:
    get:
      summary: Returns a greeting message
      responses:
        '200':
          description: A successful response
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                type: object
                properties:
                  message:
                    type: string
                    examples:
                      - Hello, world!
  • greet.yaml


OpenAPI as a Machine-Readable Format Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

OpenAPI Superstructure: Resources, Interactions, and Representations

OpenAPI Superstructure: Resources, Interactions, and Representations Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(21) OpenAPI Resources: URIs 

https://openapis.org/events
  • Individual resources are identified by uniformly defined identifiers
  • Tasks are completed by traversing a number of resources
  • Evolving APIs over time is a good practice
  • Adding resources is a good way to avoid breaking changes


OpenAPI Superstructure: Resources, Interactions, and Representations Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(22) GitHub API

  • GitHub API [https://github.com/github/rest-api-description]
    • 11MB
    • 320k lines
    • 738 paths
    • 1114 operations
    • 259 webhooks


OpenAPI Superstructure: Resources, Interactions, and Representations Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(23) OpenAPI Operations: HTTP

  • The language how clients and servers communicate
  • Request/response model where the client (almost) always initiates the interaction
  • Each request has a request method (e.g., GET)
  • Each response has a response status (e.g., 200 OK)
  • Requests and responses use header fields for metadata
  • Requests and responses can have a message body


OpenAPI Superstructure: Resources, Interactions, and Representations Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(24) OpenAPI Representations: JSON

  • JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) for exchanging structured data
  • application/json says nothing about the data itself
  • JSON Schema for describing valid structured data
  • OpenAPI uses JSON Schema for describing structured data


OpenAPI Superstructure: Resources, Interactions, and Representations Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(25) API Response: Structured Data 

{
  "login": "octocat",
  "id": 1,
  "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjE=",
  "avatar_url": "https://github.com/images/error/octocat_happy.gif",
  "gravatar_id": "",
  "url": "https://api.github.com/users/octocat",
  "html_url": "https://github.com/octocat",
  "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/octocat/followers",
  "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/octocat/following{/other_user}",
  "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/octocat/gists{/gist_id}",
  "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/octocat/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
  "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/octocat/subscriptions",
  "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/octocat/orgs",
  "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/octocat/repos",
  • octocat.json (line 1-15)


OpenAPI Superstructure: Resources, Interactions, and Representations Erik Wilde: API Descriptions and OpenAPI

(26) API Response with Media Type 

paths:
  "/users/{username}":
    get:
      summary: Get a user
      operationId: users/get-by-username
      parameters:
        - name: username
          description: The handle for the GitHub user account.
          in: path
          required: true
          schema:
            type: string
      responses:
        '200':
          description: Response
          content:
            application/json:
              schema:
                oneOf:
                  - "$ref": "#/components/schemas/private-user"
                  - "$ref": "#/components/schemas/public-user"
  • github-get-by-username.yaml
